clotLocations.name: Left Upper Limb — Axillary/Brachial Vein Thrombosis
commonSymptoms: arm pain or tenderness (may worsen with movement)
clotLocations.notes: Upper-extremity DVT (axillary/brachial) is associated with central venous catheters, effort-related thrombosis (Paget–Schroetter), cancer, and thoracic outlet syndrome. Prompt imaging (duplex ultrasound) and anticoagulation are indicated according to clinical guidelines. Clinical review required.

clotLocations.name: Right Upper Limb — Axillary/Brachial Vein Thrombosis
commonSymptoms: arm pain or tenderness (may worsen with movement)
clotLocations.notes: See left-arm entry. Management and diagnosis follow the same principles.

clotLocations.name: Left Lower Limb — Femoral/Proximal DVT
commonSymptoms: calf pain or tenderness (often worse on standing/walking)
clotLocations.notes: Proximal deep vein thrombosis (femoral/iliac) carries higher risk of pulmonary embolism. Use clinical scoring (Wells score) and diagnostic testing (D-dimer, compression ultrasound) per guidelines. Clinical review required.

clotLocations.name: Right Lower Limb — Femoral/Proximal DVT
commonSymptoms: calf pain or tenderness (often worse on standing/walking)
clotLocations.notes: See left-leg entry. Proximal DVTs have elevated PE risk and should be evaluated promptly.

clotLocations.name: Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
commonSymptoms: pleuritic chest pain (worse on deep breath)
rapid heart rate, lightheadedness, or syncope
clotLocations.notes: Pulmonary embolism is a potential complication of DVT. It can be life-threatening; urgent evaluation (CT pulmonary angiography, D-dimer, leg ultrasound) and management are required. This entry is educational—clinical confirmation required.

bmi.note: Overweight increases VTE risk per CDC/NICE
Obesity significantly increases VTE risk (see JAMA/NHLBI)

riskModifiers.notes: Risk modifiers are illustrative and derived from CDC, NICE and peer-reviewed literature. Clinical scoring systems (Wells, Caprini) should be used for formal risk stratification.
